I didn't set out to write a book on on

own life I set out to figure out the

there's no meaning to life I'd better

uh I didn't get a job my first time out

assigned to teach introductory

there are a lot of these great quotes I

are I wonder how many um insights the
Ancients had so it's really just a set
of coincidences and flukes that led me
to write a book about the great
psychological truth which my publisher
then labeled a book about
happiness
I think the the greatest truths the ones
that you find in every culture that has
any sort of history of reflection and
writing uh the greatest truth is that
there's nothing good or bad but thinking
makes it so that's the way Shakespeare
put it um but you get basically the same
idea from Buddha uh from the Bhagavad
Gita in India and from the stoics in in
ancient Greece and Rome um so in
understanding that uh the world doesn't
usually affect us directly it's how it's
what we we do with it it's the filters
that we put on it uh that's the
foundation of certainly most pop
psychology uh and of a lot of
psychotherapy cognitive therapy so that
I think is the greatest truth but if you
take that to its logical conclusion you
get a psychology or philosophy of life
that says stop striving um uh look
within meditate disengage and the
conclusion I came to in writing the

contemplative life that life of

it's generally a bad idea for us
westerners uh many of us who are not

successes
uh uh and exal in them when we feel

most basic fact in Psychology is that
the mind is divided into parts that
often conflict um Freud brought this to

he had an unconscious that was deep and

you can never think about because you

feel like um there's a circle of light
I'm looking within it uh we're like the

steer the elephant and if he's not busy
he'll go where we want um but if he has

wants in part this comes with with

the frontal areas of the brain are

initial instinct to act uh this is why
